Award.AwardTitle: Education Research Grant: A Multi-Media Case Study Pedagogical Approach on Electronic Health Records for STEM Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The project will apply a tested methodological approach--a multi-metric approach to assess the impact of STEM instructional multimedia on undergraduate teaching and learning-- to the subject matter of electronic health records (EHR). The project deploy three comprehensive multimedia case studies that introduce undergraduate STEM students to electronic health records and assess the effect of this approach on student learning, including impact on higher order cognitive skills. Three constructs and criteria will be used to assess students' actual learning: 1) Learning-Driven factor, 2) Content-Driven factor, and 3) Higher-Order Cognitive Skills factor. Three inter-related qualitative and quantitative matrices will be developed to assess students' perceived learning (Perceived Learning Matrix), actual learning (Actual Learning Outcome Matrix), and learning processes (Learning Process Matrix). The innovative multimedia instructional approach developed in this project is expected to give students first-hand observational experience of EHR operations and can be used to teach other information technology topics where visualization is very important as opposed to traditional text book lecture on emerging technology issues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The following anticipated (specific) objectives were pursued and accomplished:

  1. To introduce a select sample of STEM students to electronic health records (EHR)
  2. To evaluate the effectiveness and impact of EHR multimedia case studies on students’ higher level cognitive skill development
  3. To disseminate the project’s EHR instructional materials to the STEM community

Multiple factors did underpin the rationale for these project objectives. The project representd a continuation of our prior funded NSF support (NSF 0311646 and 0527328) where we successfully adapted multimedia instructional materials to communicate engineering and information technology issues to non-technical students. Similarly, our NSF/IRES award (0927688) investigated information technology in healthcare in resource-poor settings and our NSF/HRD award (0811453) took a multi-metric approach to assess the impact of STEM instructional multimedia on undergraduate teaching and learning. This firm research footing postured us well: we have now refined the multimedia case study methodology, generated a rich pool of multimedia case studies including those focusing on electronic health records, developed and now refined novel evaluation tools, disseminated project findings widely and mentored and graduated one PhD student as a result of this project.

In summary, we applied our methodological approach to the subject matter of electronic health records (EHR); it is particularly appropriate that undergraduate students gain a solid introduction to EHR since the Federal government has set 2015 as the date by which healthcare providers must use this technology or risk reduction in Medicare and Medicaid payments. Moreover, the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Occupational Outlook Handbook (2010 Edition) indicates that of the 20 fastest growing occupations in the economy, healthcare and information technology account for over half of them, including biomedical engineers, network systems and data communications analysts, and computer software applications engineers. Our EHR project lies at the vector of healthcare and information and communications technology.
